text: Water Snake Plants every 2-3 weeks. Allow soil to dry completely between waterings. Overwatering is the most common cause of death.
Snake Plants thrive in low to bright indirect light. They can tolerate low light conditions but grow faster with more light.
Yellow leaves on Snake Plants usually indicate overwatering. Check soil moisture and reduce watering frequency.
Water Fiddle Leaf Figs when the top 2 inches of soil are dry. Water thoroughly until water drains from the bottom.
Fiddle Leaf Figs need bright, indirect light. Place near a bright window but avoid direct sunlight which can burn leaves.
Brown spots on Fiddle Leaf Fig leaves often indicate inconsistent watering. Maintain a regular watering schedule.
Dropping leaves on Fiddle Leaf Figs can be caused by overwatering, underwatering, or sudden environmental changes.
Water Monsteras when the top inch of soil is dry. They prefer consistently moist but not soggy soil.
Monsteras need bright, indirect light to develop their characteristic split leaves. Too little light results in solid leaves.
Monsteras are climbing plants that benefit from moss poles or trellises for support as they grow taller.
Water Pothos when the top inch of soil feels dry. They're forgiving plants that can tolerate some neglect.
Pothos can grow in low to bright indirect light. Variegated varieties need more light to maintain their patterns.
Pothos are easy to propagate. Cut a stem with 4-6 leaves and place in water or moist soil to root.
Water succulents deeply but infrequently. Allow soil to dry completely between waterings to prevent root rot.
Succulents need bright, direct light for at least 6 hours daily. Insufficient light causes stretching and weak growth.
Use well-draining cactus or succulent soil mix. Regular potting soil retains too much moisture for succulents.
Peace Lilies prefer consistently moist soil. Water when the top inch feels dry and mist leaves regularly.
Peace Lilies thrive in low to medium indirect light. Avoid direct sunlight which can scorch their leaves.
Drooping Peace Lily leaves usually indicate the plant needs water. They're excellent at communicating their needs.
Water Spider Plants when the top inch of soil is dry. They prefer slightly moist soil but can tolerate some drying.
Spider Plants thrive in bright, indirect light but can tolerate lower light conditions. Avoid direct sun.
Spider Plants produce baby plants (spiderettes) that can be easily propagated by placing in water or soil.
Water Aloe Vera deeply but infrequently. Allow soil to dry completely between waterings to prevent root rot.
Aloe Vera needs bright, direct light for at least 6 hours daily. Insufficient light causes weak, stretched growth.
Brown tips on Aloe Vera leaves often indicate overwatering or mineral buildup in soil. Flush soil occasionally.
Water Rubber Plants when the top 2 inches of soil are dry. They prefer slightly moist but well-draining soil.
Rubber Plants need bright, indirect light. Too little light causes leggy growth and leaf drop.
Yellow leaves on Rubber Plants often indicate overwatering. Check soil moisture and drainage.
Water ZZ Plants every 2-3 weeks. They store water in their rhizomes and prefer to dry out between waterings.
ZZ Plants can tolerate low light conditions but grow best in bright, indirect light. Avoid direct sunlight.
Fertilize houseplants during growing season (spring and summer) with balanced liquid fertilizer diluted to half strength.
Repot plants when roots are visible at drainage holes or plant becomes root-bound. Use pot one size larger.
Most houseplants prefer 40-60% humidity. Use humidifiers, pebble trays, or misting to increase humidity.
Most houseplants prefer temperatures between 65-75°F (18-24°C). Avoid drafts and sudden temperature changes.
Brown leaf tips often indicate low humidity, over-fertilization, or water quality issues. Check all care factors.
Water Snake Plants every 2-3 weeks during growing season, less in winter. Allow soil to dry completely between waterings. Overwatering causes root rot.
Snake Plants thrive in low to bright indirect light. They can survive in very low light but grow faster with more light. Avoid direct sun.
Yellow leaves indicate overwatering. Brown tips suggest underwatering. Drooping leaves mean too much water. Check soil moisture.
Water Fiddle Leaf Figs when top 2 inches of soil are dry. Water thoroughly until it drains from bottom. Inconsistent watering causes leaf drop.
Fiddle Leaf Figs need bright, indirect light. Place near east or west-facing window. Rotate plant weekly for even growth.
Brown spots on leaves indicate inconsistent watering. Dropping leaves mean overwatering, underwatering, or sudden changes. Maintain consistent care.
Water Monstera when top inch of soil is dry. Water thoroughly and allow excess to drain. Overwatering causes yellow leaves.
Monsteras prefer bright, indirect light. Too much direct sun burns leaves. Too little light reduces leaf fenestrations.
Monsteras love high humidity (60-80%). Use humidifier, pebble tray, or mist regularly. Low humidity causes brown leaf edges.
Water Pothos when soil feels dry to touch. These plants are drought-tolerant and prefer to dry out between waterings.
Pothos adapts to various light conditions from low to bright indirect light. Variegated varieties need more light to maintain patterns.
Pothos propagates easily in water or soil. Cut below a node and place in water. Roots develop in 1-2 weeks.
Water succulents deeply but infrequently. Soak soil completely, then let dry out completely. Water every 1-2 weeks in growing season.
Succulents need bright, direct light for 6+ hours daily. Insufficient light causes stretching and loss of color.
Use well-draining soil mix for succulents. Add perlite or sand to regular potting soil. Ensure pots have drainage holes.
Water Peace Lily when soil surface feels dry. These plants droop dramatically when thirsty, making watering needs obvious.
Peace Lilies prefer low to medium indirect light. Too much direct sun burns leaves. They can survive in low light but may not flower.
Brown leaf tips indicate overwatering or water quality issues. Yellow leaves mean overwatering. Drooping means underwatering.
Water Spider Plants when soil feels dry to touch. These plants are forgiving and can handle occasional overwatering.
Spider Plants thrive in bright, indirect light but can adapt to lower light. Avoid direct sun which can burn leaves.
Spider Plants produce baby plants on long stems. Cut babies and root in water or soil. Very easy to propagate.
Water Aloe Vera deeply but infrequently. Let soil dry completely between waterings. Overwatering causes root rot.
Aloe Vera needs bright, direct sunlight for 6+ hours daily. Insufficient light causes stretching and weak growth.
Aloe Vera gel has healing properties for burns and cuts. Use fresh gel from inner leaf. Store unused gel in refrigerator.
Water Rubber Plant when top inch of soil is dry. These plants prefer consistent moisture but not soggy soil.
Rubber Plants need bright, indirect light. Too little light causes leaf drop. Rotate plant for even growth.
Yellow leaves indicate overwatering. Brown leaf edges suggest low humidity. Clean leaves regularly for better photosynthesis.
Water ZZ Plant every 2-3 weeks. These plants store water in rhizomes and can survive long periods without water.
ZZ Plants tolerate low light but grow faster in bright, indirect light. They can survive in very low light conditions.
Yellow leaves usually indicate overwatering. ZZ Plants are very drought-tolerant and prefer to be underwatered.
Water Philodendron when top inch of soil is dry. These plants prefer consistent moisture but not waterlogged soil.
Philodendrons prefer bright, indirect light but can tolerate lower light. Avoid direct sun which burns leaves.
Philodendrons are natural climbers. Provide moss pole or trellis for support. Climbing varieties grow larger leaves.
Water Chinese Money Plant when soil feels dry. These plants prefer to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot.
Chinese Money Plants need bright, indirect light. Too little light causes leggy growth. Rotate plant for even growth.
Chinese Money Plants produce baby plants at base. Separate babies when they have 3-4 leaves and root in water or soil.
Water Jade Plant when soil is completely dry. These succulents store water in leaves and prefer infrequent watering.
Jade Plants need bright, direct light for 4+ hours daily. Insufficient light causes stretching and weak stems.
Wrinkled leaves indicate underwatering. Yellow leaves suggest overwatering. Dropping leaves mean inconsistent watering.
Water String of Pearls when pearls start to shrivel slightly. These succulents prefer to dry out between waterings.
String of Pearls needs bright, indirect light. Too little light causes stretching and weak pearls. Avoid direct sun.
Shriveled pearls indicate underwatering. Yellow pearls suggest overwatering. Ensure good drainage to prevent root rot.
Water Calathea when top inch of soil is dry. These plants prefer consistently moist soil but not waterlogged.
Calathea needs high humidity (60-80%). Use humidifier or pebble tray. Low humidity causes brown, crispy leaf edges.
Calathea prefers bright, indirect light. Too much direct sun fades leaf patterns. Too little light reduces variegation.
Water Bird of Paradise when top 2 inches of soil are dry. These plants prefer deep, infrequent watering.
Bird of Paradise needs bright, indirect light. Some direct morning sun is beneficial. Too little light prevents flowering.
Split leaves are normal for Bird of Paradise. Brown leaf tips indicate low humidity. Clean leaves regularly.
Water Lavender sparingly. These plants prefer to dry out between waterings. Overwatering causes root rot.
Lavender needs full sun for 6+ hours daily. Insufficient light causes leggy growth and poor flowering.
Lavender needs well-draining soil. Add sand or perlite to improve drainage. Avoid rich, water-retentive soils.
Water Echeveria when soil is completely dry. Soak thoroughly and let excess water drain. Reduce watering in winter.
Echeveria needs bright, direct sunlight for 6+ hours daily. Place near south-facing windows for best results.
Use well-draining cactus/succulent soil mix. Add perlite or sand to improve drainage.
Propagate Echeveria from leaf cuttings. Let leaves callous for 2-3 days before placing on soil.
Yellow, mushy leaves indicate overwatering. Brown, crispy leaves mean underwatering or too much sun.
Water Barrel Cactus monthly in summer, every 2-3 months in winter. Let soil dry completely between waterings.
Barrel Cactus thrives in full sun. Provide 8+ hours of direct sunlight daily.
Use fast-draining cactus soil. Mix regular potting soil with sand and perlite for better drainage.
Fertilize Barrel Cactus once in spring with diluted cactus fertilizer. Avoid over-fertilizing.
Keep Christmas Cactus soil evenly moist but not soggy. Water when top inch of soil feels dry.
Christmas Cactus prefers bright, indirect light. Avoid direct sun which can burn leaves.
To encourage blooming, provide 12-14 hours of darkness daily for 6-8 weeks before desired bloom time.
Christmas Cactus prefers temperatures between 60-70°F. Cooler temps help trigger flowering.
Water Basil when top inch of soil is dry. Keep soil consistently moist but not waterlogged.
Basil needs 6-8 hours of bright, direct sunlight daily. Place in south-facing window or under grow lights.
Harvest Basil by pinching off leaves above a node. This encourages bushier growth.
Pinch off flower buds to prevent bolting and maintain leaf production.
Feed Basil with balanced liquid fertilizer every 2-3 weeks during growing season.
Keep Mint soil consistently moist. Water when top inch feels dry to touch.
Mint grows best in partial shade to full sun. 4-6 hours of sunlight is ideal.
Plant Mint in containers to prevent spreading. It can be invasive in garden beds.
Harvest Mint by cutting stems just above a leaf node. Regular harvesting promotes growth.
Propagate Mint easily from stem cuttings placed in water until roots form.
Water Rosemary when soil is dry to touch. Allow soil to dry between waterings to prevent root rot.
Rosemary needs full sun - at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight daily.
Use well-draining soil with sand or perlite. Rosemary prefers slightly alkaline soil.
Prune Rosemary regularly to maintain shape and encourage new growth. Never cut into woody stems.
Protect Rosemary from freezing temperatures. Move indoors or cover during cold spells.
Water African Violets from bottom to avoid wetting leaves. Use room temperature water.
African Violets prefer bright, indirect light. East or north-facing windows work well.
African Violets need high humidity. Place on pebble tray or use humidifier.
Feed African Violets with balanced fertilizer every 2-3 weeks during growing season.
Repot African Violets annually in spring. Use shallow pots as they have shallow root systems.
Water Orchids when potting medium is nearly dry. Soak thoroughly and drain completely.
Orchids need bright, indirect light. East-facing windows provide ideal conditions.
Orchids require 50-70% humidity. Use humidifier or pebble tray to increase moisture.
Fertilize Orchids weekly with diluted orchid fertilizer during growing season.
Repot Orchids every 1-2 years using orchid-specific potting mix with bark and moss.
Water Geraniums when soil surface feels dry. Water thoroughly and allow excess to drain.
Geraniums need full sun - at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily for best flowering.
Remove spent flowers regularly to encourage continuous blooming throughout season.
Feed Geraniums with balanced fertilizer every 2-3 weeks during growing season.
Overwinter Geraniums indoors in cool, bright location. Reduce watering in winter.
Water Bird of Paradise when top 2 inches of soil are dry. Water deeply and allow to drain.
Bird of Paradise needs bright, indirect light. Some direct morning sun is beneficial.
Bird of Paradise prefers high humidity. Mist leaves regularly or use humidifier.
Feed Bird of Paradise monthly with balanced liquid fertilizer during growing season.
Repot Bird of Paradise every 2-3 years in spring. Use well-draining potting mix.
Water Rubber Plant when top inch of soil is dry. Allow soil to dry between waterings.
Rubber Plant thrives in bright, indirect light. Can tolerate some direct morning sun.
Wipe Rubber Plant leaves regularly with damp cloth to remove dust and improve photosynthesis.
Prune Rubber Plant to control height and encourage branching. Cut just above a leaf node.
Propagate Rubber Plant from stem cuttings. Root in water or moist soil.
Water Dracaena when soil is dry to touch. These plants are drought tolerant.
Dracaena prefers bright, indirect light. Can tolerate lower light conditions.
Feed Dracaena monthly with balanced liquid fertilizer during growing season.
Brown leaf tips on Dracaena usually indicate overwatering or low humidity.
Repot Dracaena every 2-3 years when roots fill the container.
Keep Boston Fern soil consistently moist but not soggy. Water when top inch feels dry.
Boston Fern prefers bright, indirect light. Avoid direct sun which can burn fronds.
Boston Fern needs high humidity. Mist daily or place on pebble tray with water.
Feed Boston Fern monthly with diluted liquid fertilizer during growing season.
Repot Boston Fern annually in spring. Use peat-based potting mix.
Keep Maidenhair Fern soil evenly moist. Never let it dry out completely.
Maidenhair Fern needs bright, indirect light. East-facing windows are ideal.
Maidenhair Fern requires very high humidity. Consider using a terrarium or humidifier.
Maidenhair Fern prefers temperatures between 60-75°F. Avoid drafts and cold air.
Brown, crispy fronds on Maidenhair Fern indicate low humidity or underwatering.
Water Pothos when top inch of soil is dry. Allow soil to dry between waterings.
Pothos tolerates low to bright indirect light. Variegated varieties need more light.
Feed Pothos monthly with balanced liquid fertilizer during growing season.
Propagate Pothos easily from stem cuttings in water or soil.
Prune Pothos to control length and encourage bushiness. Cut just above a leaf node.
Water Philodendron when top inch of soil is dry. Water thoroughly and drain excess.
Philodendron prefers bright, indirect light. Can tolerate lower light conditions.
Feed Philodendron monthly with balanced liquid fertilizer during growing season.
Provide moss pole or trellis for climbing Philodendron varieties to grow upward.
Repot Philodendron every 2-3 years when roots fill the container.
Keep English Ivy soil evenly moist. Water when top inch feels dry to touch.
English Ivy prefers bright, indirect light. Can tolerate lower light conditions.
English Ivy appreciates higher humidity. Mist leaves regularly or use humidifier.
Feed English Ivy monthly with balanced liquid fertilizer during growing season.
Prune English Ivy regularly to control growth and maintain desired shape.
Soak Tillandsia in water for 20-30 minutes weekly. Shake off excess water after soaking.
Tillandsia needs bright, indirect light. Some varieties can tolerate direct morning sun.
Tillandsia needs good air circulation. Avoid placing in enclosed containers.
Fertilize Tillandsia monthly with diluted bromeliad or air plant fertilizer.
Display Tillandsia on driftwood, rocks, or in open terrariums for best results.
Water Areca Palm when top inch of soil is dry. Keep soil evenly moist but not soggy.
Areca Palm prefers bright, indirect light. Avoid direct sun which can burn leaves.
Areca Palm needs high humidity. Mist regularly or use humidifier.
Feed Areca Palm monthly with palm-specific fertilizer during growing season.
Repot Areca Palm every 2-3 years in spring. Use well-draining potting mix.
Water Kentia Palm when top 2 inches of soil are dry. Water deeply and allow to drain.
Kentia Palm tolerates low to bright indirect light. Avoid direct sun.
Kentia Palm appreciates higher humidity. Mist leaves regularly.
Feed Kentia Palm monthly with balanced liquid fertilizer during growing season.
Wipe Kentia Palm leaves with damp cloth to remove dust and improve appearance.
Most houseplants prefer to dry out slightly between waterings. Check soil moisture with your finger.
Bright, indirect light means near a window but not in direct sunbeams. East-facing windows are ideal.
Fertilize houseplants monthly during growing season (spring through fall) with balanced liquid fertilizer.
Repot plants when roots fill the container or grow out of drainage holes. Spring is the best time.
Always use pots with drainage holes to prevent root rot from waterlogged soil.
Most houseplants prefer temperatures between 65-75°F. Avoid drafts and extreme temperature changes.
Group plants together or use pebble trays to increase humidity around your plants.
Check plants regularly for pests like spider mites, mealybugs, and aphids. Treat early for best results.
Wipe plant leaves regularly with damp cloth to remove dust and improve photosynthesis.
Rotate plants weekly to ensure even growth and prevent leaning toward light sources.
Water Jade Plant when soil is completely dry. These succulents store water in their leaves.
Jade Plant needs bright light for 4-6 hours daily. Some direct sun is beneficial.
Prune Jade Plant to maintain shape and encourage branching. Cut above leaf nodes.
Propagate Jade Plant from stem or leaf cuttings. Let cuttings dry before planting.
Feed Jade Plant monthly with diluted succulent fertilizer during growing season.
Water Hens and Chicks sparingly. Let soil dry completely between waterings.
Hens and Chicks need full sun - at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily.
Hens and Chicks produce offsets that can be separated and replanted.
Hens and Chicks are cold hardy and can survive winter outdoors in many climates.
Use well-draining soil mix with sand or perlite for Hens and Chicks.
Water String of Pearls when soil is dry. These plants are very drought tolerant.
String of Pearls needs bright, indirect light. Some direct morning sun is okay.
String of Pearls looks best in hanging baskets where stems can cascade down.
Propagate String of Pearls by placing stem cuttings on soil surface.
Shriveled pearls indicate underwatering. Mushy pearls mean overwatering.
Water Thyme when soil feels dry. These herbs prefer slightly dry conditions.
Thyme needs full sun - at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily.
Harvest Thyme by cutting stems just above a leaf node. Regular harvesting promotes growth.
Prune Thyme regularly to prevent woody growth and maintain compact shape.
Thyme is perennial and can survive winter in many climates with protection.
Water Oregano when soil is dry to touch. These herbs prefer well-drained soil.
Oregano thrives in full sun. Provide at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily.
Harvest Oregano leaves before flowering for best flavor. Cut stems above leaf nodes.
Feed Oregano lightly with balanced fertilizer once in spring.
Propagate Oregano from stem cuttings or by dividing established plants.
Water Sage when soil is dry. These herbs are drought tolerant once established.
Sage needs full sun for best growth and flavor development.
Harvest Sage leaves as needed. Pick before flowering for best flavor.
Prune Sage in spring to remove dead growth and encourage new shoots.
Sage is hardy and can survive winter in many climates with minimal protection.
Water Begonia when top inch of soil is dry. Keep soil evenly moist but not soggy.
Begonia prefers bright, indirect light. Some varieties can handle direct morning sun.
Begonia appreciates higher humidity. Mist leaves regularly or use humidifier.
Feed Begonia monthly with balanced liquid fertilizer during growing season.
Remove spent flowers regularly to encourage continuous blooming.
Keep Impatiens soil consistently moist. These plants wilt quickly when dry.
Impatiens prefer partial shade. Too much direct sun can burn the leaves.
Feed Impatiens every 2 weeks with balanced liquid fertilizer for best blooms.
Pinch back Impatiens to encourage bushier growth and more flowers.
Propagate Impatiens easily from stem cuttings in water or moist soil.
Water Petunias regularly to keep soil moist. They need consistent moisture for best blooms.
Petunias need full sun - at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily.
Deadhead Petunias regularly to encourage continuous flowering throughout season.
Feed Petunias weekly with high-phosphorus fertilizer for abundant blooms.
Cut back leggy Petunias by half to encourage bushier growth and more flowers.
Keep Calathea soil evenly moist but not soggy. Use filtered or distilled water.
Calathea prefers bright, indirect light. Avoid direct sun which can fade leaf patterns.
Calathea needs high humidity. Mist daily or use humidifier to prevent brown edges.
Calathea prefers temperatures between 65-80°F. Avoid cold drafts.
Feed Calathea monthly with diluted liquid fertilizer during growing season.
Water Maranta when top inch of soil is dry. Keep soil consistently moist.
Maranta prefers bright, indirect light. Too much sun can fade the leaf patterns.
Maranta needs high humidity. Place on pebble tray or use humidifier.
Maranta leaves move throughout the day - this is normal behavior.
Feed Maranta monthly with balanced liquid fertilizer during growing season.
Water Anthurium when top inch of soil is dry. Keep soil evenly moist.
Anthurium needs bright, indirect light. Some direct morning sun is beneficial.
Anthurium appreciates high humidity. Mist leaves regularly or use humidifier.
Feed Anthurium monthly with balanced liquid fertilizer for best flowering.
Repot Anthurium every 2-3 years in spring using well-draining potting mix.
Water Tradescantia when top inch of soil is dry. Allow soil to dry between waterings.
Tradescantia needs bright, indirect light. Variegated varieties need more light.
Feed Tradescantia monthly with balanced liquid fertilizer during growing season.
Propagate Tradescantia easily from stem cuttings in water or soil.
Prune Tradescantia regularly to maintain shape and encourage bushiness.
Water String of Hearts when soil is dry. These succulents store water in their leaves.
String of Hearts needs bright, indirect light. Some direct morning sun is okay.
String of Hearts looks beautiful in hanging baskets where it can cascade down.
Propagate String of Hearts from stem cuttings or by placing tubers on soil.
Feed String of Hearts monthly with diluted succulent fertilizer during growing season.
Water Hoya when soil is dry to touch. These plants prefer to dry out between waterings.
Hoya needs bright, indirect light. Some direct morning sun can encourage flowering.
Feed Hoya monthly with balanced liquid fertilizer during growing season.
Hoya flowers on old spurs, so avoid cutting them off when pruning.
Hoya prefers to be root-bound. Only repot when absolutely necessary.
Water Staghorn Fern by soaking the root ball weekly. Let it drain completely.
Staghorn Fern needs bright, indirect light. Some direct morning sun is beneficial.
Mount Staghorn Fern on wood or cork bark for best growth and display.
Feed Staghorn Fern monthly with diluted liquid fertilizer during growing season.
Staghorn Fern needs high humidity. Mist regularly or use humidifier.
Keep Rabbit Foot Fern soil evenly moist. Water when top inch feels dry.
Rabbit Foot Fern prefers bright, indirect light. Avoid direct sun.
Rabbit Foot Fern needs high humidity. Place on pebble tray with water.
Feed Rabbit Foot Fern monthly with balanced liquid fertilizer during growing season.
Repot Rabbit Foot Fern annually in spring using peat-based potting mix.
Water Parlor Palm when top inch of soil is dry. Keep soil evenly moist.
Parlor Palm tolerates low to bright indirect light. Avoid direct sun.
Parlor Palm appreciates higher humidity. Mist leaves regularly.
Feed Parlor Palm monthly with balanced liquid fertilizer during growing season.
Repot Parlor Palm every 2-3 years in spring when roots fill the container.
Water Lady Palm when top 2 inches of soil are dry. Water deeply and allow to drain.
Lady Palm prefers bright, indirect light. Can tolerate lower light conditions.
Lady Palm needs high humidity. Mist regularly or use humidifier.
Feed Lady Palm monthly with palm-specific fertilizer during growing season.
Remove dead or yellow fronds by cutting at the base of the stem.
Spring is the best time for repotting, fertilizing, and propagating most houseplants.
Summer is peak growing season. Increase watering and fertilizing frequency.
Fall is time to reduce fertilizing and prepare plants for winter dormancy.
Winter care involves reducing watering, stopping fertilizing, and providing adequate light.
Many plants go dormant in winter. Reduce watering and stop fertilizing during this time.
Yellow leaves often indicate overwatering, underwatering, or nutrient deficiency.
Brown leaf tips usually indicate low humidity, over-fertilizing, or water quality issues.
Drooping leaves can mean underwatering, overwatering, or root problems.
Lack of growth may indicate insufficient light, nutrients, or need for repotting.
Leaf drop can be caused by overwatering, underwatering, or environmental stress.
Common pests include spider mites, mealybugs, aphids, and scale insects.
Plant diseases often result from overwatering, poor air circulation, or contaminated soil.
Root rot is caused by overwatering. Remove affected roots and repot in fresh soil.
Wilting can indicate underwatering, overwatering, or root damage.
Stunted growth may indicate insufficient light, nutrients, or need for larger pot.
